Stylised BP model used to estimate likelihood of observing secondary infections/generations, fitted to data for same. Transmission route is human-human but unspecific as to closeness of contact. Assumptions: Heterogenity in transmission rates - between human and vector,Heterogenity in transmission rates - over time,Other
model_fitting_method: The model was fitted to data using maximum likelihood and Bayesian inference (Gibbs sampling)
model_notes: Case data were taken from WHO and Rambaut's curated repository, but not published with this paper. For assumptions, the model assumes a constant reporting rate (rho) across different regions and over time. It also primarily uses a fixed generation time of one week.They also used the GLEAM model but this is not the first time it was reported. GLEAM is a global, stochastic, metapopulation model (GLEAM) using an SEIR framework. It was parameterized with the time- and space-varying transmission rates from Model 1 and fitted to the observed number of MERS-CoV cases imported into countries outside the Middle East to estimate the overall reporting rate. This is a weird hybrid of a statistical and mechanistic model, but it does model transmission. 'incidence was modelled as the superposition of sporadic cases at a region-specific time-varying weekly rate pr sp(t) and of cases caused by human-to-human transmission with region-specific time-varying reproduction ratio Rr(t).'

Assumptions: Heterogenity in transmission rates - over time,Other
model_notes: Explicitly models superspreading events. Model is only for hospital population - nosocomial infections/setting. Intervention is isolation of infected patient. Mention use of PPE and being in the same room as others, ventiliation etc. So airborne could be relevant here although not explicitly written.

model_compartmental_other: SEAIHR. Where A is asymptomatic, I is total number mild infected person and severe patients and H is the number of hospitalised cases.

Assumptions: Homogeneous mixing,Latent period is same as incubation period
Heterogenity in transmission rates - between human groups
model_notes: This is a stochastic SEIR agent-based model developed to understand super-spreading events in the 2015 Korean MERS-CoV outbreak. The authors tested four variations: a baseline with no super-spreaders (No-SS), a model where super-spreaders have higher infectivity (SSM1), one where they have more contacts (SSM2), and a hybrid model where they have both (SSM3). The results were compared to real-world data, and SSM3 was found to provide the best fit. The model also explored the impact of random and targeted isolation interventions.
